data.title: Noted Christian Kirk Cameron says wives must 'honour and respect and follow their husband's lead'
data.meta_description: 'When each person gets their part right, regardless of how their spouse is treating them, there is hope for real change in their marriage'
data.text:
'When each person gets their part right, regardless of how their spouse is treating them, there is hope for real change in their marriage'

Reviews and recommendations are unbiased and products are independently selected. Postmedia may earn an affiliate commission from purchases made through links on this page.

Article content

If you’re having marriage trouble, don’t worry. Kirk Cameron is here to offer his advice.

In an interview with the Christian Post, the former Growing Pains star said, “Wives are to honour and respect and follow their husband’s lead, not to tell their husband how he ought to be a better husband. When each person gets their part right, regardless of how their spouse is treating them, there is hope for real change in their marriage.”

Cameron has long been an active and vocal evangelical Christian, married to actress Chelsea Noble since 1991, the pair have six children. He is currently on a Bible event tour called “Love Worth Fighting For,” which is meant to teach others how to “strengthen and encourage” their marriage.

In the interview, he added that “a lot of people don’t know that marriage comes with instructions,” and “we find them right there in God’s word.”

This isn’t the first time Cameron has shared his thoughts and been met with heavy backlash. He recently told Piers Morgan that homosexuality is “destructive to so many of the foundations of civilization.”

“How did you like the Grammy’s all out assault on the traditional family last night?” he wrote after Macklemore and Ryan Lewis’ performance of “Same Love,” in which 33 couples, both gay and straight, were married.

Cameron’s younger sister, Candace Cameron Bure, who plays D.J. Fuller, formerly Tanner, on Netflix’s Fuller House, shares similar views to her brother. She recently made headlines when she said of her marriage to former NHLer Valeri Bure that submissiveness is key in a wife.

“I love that my man is a leader,” she told HuffPo Live in 2014. “I want him to lead and be the head of the family and those decisions, major decisions, do fall on him. It doesn’t mean I don’t voice my opinion. It doesn’t mean I don’t have an opinion. I absolutely do. … “But it is very difficult to have two heads of authority.”
